funder.name: EU Framework Horizon 2020 Innovation Grant, European Virus Archive

abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In mainland Europe, the mosquito species <jats:italic>Culex modestus</jats:italic> Ficalbi (1890) is a bridge vector for West Nile virus (WNV) from its natural bird‐mosquito cycle to mammals. The present study assessed the genetic diversity of <jats:italic>Cx. modestus</jats:italic>, as well as related <jats:italic>Culex</jats:italic> species, using the mitochondrial <jats:italic>COI</jats:italic> DNA barcoding region and compared this with the population structure across Europe. A haplotype network was mapped to determine genealogical relationships among specimens. The intraspecific genetic diversity within individual <jats:italic>Culex</jats:italic> species was below 2%, whereas the interspecific genetic divergence varied from 2.99% to 13.74%. In total, 76 haplotypes were identified among 198 sequences. A median‐joining network determined from 198 <jats:italic>COI</jats:italic> sequences identified two major lineages that were separated by at least four mutation steps. A high level of intraspecific genetic diversity was not detected in <jats:italic>Cx. modestus</jats:italic> in samples submitted from different European populations, which indicates that morphologically identified specimens represent a single species and not a species complex. Therefore, it is deduced that different populations of <jats:italic>Cx. modestus</jats:italic> will show a similar potential to transmit WNV, lending support to concerns that the population present in southeast England represents a risk of transmission to humans.</jats:p>
title: Genetic diversity and population structure of Culex modestus across Europe: does recent appearance in the United Kingdom reveal a tendency for geographical spread?
